fields.description:
Currently, code snippets can be nested inside expanders inside page section divider elements, but code snippets cannot be nested insider expanders inside table cells.

 

This makes it really hard to build tables that demonstrate what a piece of code is doing.  I originally thought this was a niche scenario, but its come up several times now.  The workaround is to change the text to be formatted as Code, but it's rather klunky.

 

An alternative fix would be to restore the old Confluence Cloud pages features that allowed collapsible code snippets.  Collapsible code snippets are basically expanders plus code snippets.

 

My final piece of feedback is that it's annoying that when you insert a code snippet in an expander (inside a page section divider), it automatically creates a new paragraph within the expander.  I then have to backspace twice in order to avoid excessive leading negative white space before the snippet.
fields.summary: Nest code snippets inside expanders inside table cells

h3. Issue Summary

If an anonymous user searches for something with content search API, and the query happens to get a hit on a user, the API returns a 403 error.

Example of a search query that matches a user and returns 403: (open using fresh incognito window):
[https://refined.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/search?cql=title%20~%20%22emil%22%20]

But if the anonymous user's search query does NOT have a user match in the result set, it returns the API results successfully (200)

Example of non-user matching search, returning 200 + results: (open using fresh incognito window):
[https://refined.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/search?cql=title%20~%20"partners"%20 |https://refined.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/search?cql=title%20~%20%22partners%22%20]


NOTE: This bug report is about receiving a 403 on anonymous content search API calls whenever there's a user profile match on the query. We do not expect user profile matches to be included at all on this method; however, we also expect that a user match shouldn't affect this query at all.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open incognito window to insure you're not logged in
 # Call content search API, searching for a title for a known username on instance: [https://refined.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/search?cql=title%20~%20%22emil%22%20]

h3. Expected Results

API call succeeds whether or not the query finds a user profile match. 
h3. Actual Results

403 error on CQL queries that find a hit/match on user profile.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Confluence content search API returns 403 for anonymous users when there is a user match in results set

h3. Issue Summary


In the documentation for 'Delete content' [https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/api-group-content/#api-api-content-id-delete]
{code:java}
DELETE /wiki/rest/api/content/{id}{code}
it states that status 200 is returned if the content is successfully trashed.

 

However, when you run the endpoint you get back 204 status code whether you specify a status query parameter or not. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a page in Confluence

 # Run the delete content endpoint again in postman this time add the `status=trashed` query parameter.  204 is returned as expected which is listed in the documentation as successfully purged.

When running the delete content endpoint without the status query parameter I should expect back a http status code of 200 per documentation.

A status code of 204 is returned.
h3. Workaround

None

*Origins of the issue*

This was originally raised on the Developer Community [https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/custom-content-trashed-status/40227] the poster is looking for how to determine if a piece of content was trashed or purged based on the status code.
fields.summary: Delete content REST API status codes return 204 for trashed (200 expected per docs)

h3. Issue Summary

When using the [Confluence API to search titles|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/api-group-search/#api-api-search-get] with the tilde character (~), it will add specific characters into the specific part where the CQL is being used.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Use the API search with the tilde character for a title. For example:

{code}
https://example.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/search?cql=title~test
{code}

h3. Expected Results
The title for the page should return as expected.

h3. Actual Results
The page includes the "@" and other characters into its title. Like the example below, which would go for a page called "Testing Word Import"

{code}"@@@hl@@@Testing@@@endhl@@@ Word import"{code}

(i) Notes about the issue:

* This does not happen for pages with a single word title.
* The characters are added to where the CQL is used. Using the same example above, if it is changed for the "Word" part, instead:

{code}https://example.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/search?cql=title~word{code}

Results in:

{code}"Testing @@@hl@@@Word@@@endhl@@@ import"{code}

h3. Workaround

Try using the method to [search content by CQL|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/api-group-content/#api-api-content-search-get], which adds the extra "/content" part to the search. For example:

{code}https://example.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/content/search?cql=title~test{code}
fields.summary: CQL API search with a tilde character add characters to the page titles

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When we perform a space/site export, there's no way to run the integrity checking on the downloaded file. This is crucial especially when handling the large backup files (eg: >1GB).

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the ability to generate the MD5 checksum from Confluence.

h3. Why this is important
* Reduce the time in troubleshooting the backup file for migration.
** Example: After spending hours to upload the backup into another instance, then Confluence is telling the file cannot be processed due to the corrupted backup file. With MD5 checksum, we can validate the downloaded file before running the restoration.
* Make sure we get the working backup file for future use.
** Example: We generate the backup file in case of disaster recovery purpose or before we delete a space/site. It's not good to find out the backup file is actually corrupted after months, when we would like to restore the space/site.
fields.summary: Provide the ability to generate MD5 Checksum on space/site backup file

h3. Issue Summary

According to our [documentation|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/move-copy-and-hide-pages/], moving a page from one Space to another requires permissions to *view* and *delete* pages in the original Space, and permissions to *view* and *add* pages in the destination Space. However, when trying to move a draft (unpublished page), the move dialog won't suggest Spaces that you don't have *admin* permission.

(i) This bug only affects the new editor.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create one Space with your admin user (let's call it *Admin Space*).
 # Grant *view pages, add pages, and admin* permissions to a test user (let's call it *Test User*) on it.
 # Create another Space with your admin user (let's call it *Not Admin*).
 # Grant *view and add pages* permissions to *Test User* on it.
 # Create a third Space with your admin user (let's call it *Test Space*).
 # Grant *view, add and delete pages* permissions to *Test User* on it.
 # While logged as the *Test User*, create a page on *Test Space*.
 # While editing the page, click on the three ellipses on the top right > *Move page*.
 # On the *Space* field, enter the keyword *Admin*.

h3. Expected Results

As the user has permissions to view and create pages on both *Admin Space* and *Not Admin*, both Spaces should return on the dialog.
h3. Actual Results

Only Spaces in which the user is an admin are found (in this example, only *Admin Space*).
h3. Workaround

The user is able to move the page after publishing it. This bug only affects the ability to move *drafts*. That being said, the user is able to publish the page on the original Space, and then click on the three ellipses on the top right corner > *Move*. In there, all the expected Spaces will be listed.
fields.summary: Users are not able to move a draft unless they have admin permission on the new Space

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When publishing a page, the "page history" and "last modified" information is associated with the user who did it in order to correctly track modifications.

It would be beneficial to allow the users to select if they want to edit or comment on a page anonymously. This could help in terms of gathering feedback and encourage users to include anonymous information for pages where they are allowed to.
h3. Suggestion

Although Confluence allows [setting up the site to the public|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/set-up-public-access/], this would open it for anyone around the world. Similar to hiding the page author and history for certain users, this would be a feature to allow the administrators to select if users to anonymously edit pages/add comments.

The feature could work with some configurations like the following ones:
 * Permission in the space to allow users to select if they want to publish pages anonymously.
 * A restriction in the page to allow only specific users to use the feature, which would be only visible to administrators (otherwise, anyone would be able to see who's the anonymous user)
 * A configuration at the user profile level would allow the publishes to be done anonymously.
fields.summary: Allow anonymous editing/comment for logged-in users
